Key Arguments: The legislation empowers an unelected body (ACMA) to determine truth online, which is seen as an assault on democracy and freedom of speech.
The government is exempt from the legislation, which is viewed as hypocritical.
Governments and their agencies cannot be trusted to define 'misinformation' as they often trade on misinformation themselves.
The definition of 'harm' in the legislation is vague and could suppress important political debates and alternate views.
The legislation could lead to censorship of discussions on multiculturalism, immigration, and other sensitive topics.
The legislation could suppress Christian and minority views that differ from prevailing cultural norms.
Notable Quotes: This is an assault on democracy and an affront to freedom of speech and conscience.
The duty of good government in a democracy, is to uphold the common good of the people it governs.

The obvious attempt of this draft Censorship Bill to frame the Government as the 'Ministry of Truth' as in George Orwell's book '1984' is an attempt to give it authoritarian powers to censor and control its citizens.
